articles.title: The deep ocean has a missing link and scientists finally found it
articles.summary: Scientists have uncovered why big predators like sharks spend so much time in the ocean’s twilight zone. The answer lies with mid-sized fish such as the bigscale pomfret, which live deep during the day and rise at night to feed, linking deep and surface food webs. Using satellite tags, researchers tracked these hard-to-study fish for the first time. Their movements shift with water clarity, potentially altering entire ocean food chains.
articles.content:
Scientists at the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution (WHOI) have found that large sharks can spend hours far below the ocean surface in the mesopelagic zone, a layer stretching from 200 to 1,000 meters (650 to 3,300 feet) deep. This dim region contains more living biomass than any other part of the ocean. Yet most of that life is made up of very small organisms, raising a long-standing question about why large predators would linger there for so long.

New research published in Marine Ecology Progress Series points to the importance of mid-sized predators, including the bigscale pomfret, in connecting deep and shallow ocean ecosystems. These fish appear to serve as a crucial link between the surface and the depths. Until recently, scientists lacked detailed information about how bigscale pomfret and similar species move through the ocean, limiting understanding of their ecological role.

To close that gap, researchers turned to satellite-based tracking tags. This technology allowed them to follow the movements of bigscale pomfret over time, something that had been difficult to achieve with deep-sea fish.

Tracking Life in the Twilight Zone

"The data shows bigscale pomfret are permanent residents of the ocean's twilight zone, and follow the pattern of diel migration. This means they stay deep during the day and come to shallower waters to feed at night," said Martin Arostegui, lead author of the study and a research associate at WHOI.

Tracking enough of these constantly moving fish posed a challenge. "Since these species spend a majority of their life on the move and in hard-to-reach places, it wouldn't have been possible for us to tag enough of them during a few days at sea. Thus, we collaborated with a commercial longline fisher, Captain Danny Mears, who did that work as part of our research team."

Collaboration With Commercial Fishers

Mears and his crew were eager to participate in the project. "Bigscale pomfret are so different from the tunas and swordfish we usually catch that we are fascinated by them whenever they show up in our gear," Mears said. "My crew and I were excited for the opportunity to help with the satellite tagging for this study. It's been very rewarding to see the data."

The study also sheds light on how environmental conditions influence bigscale pomfret behavior. When the fish traveled from the Slope Sea into the clearer waters of the Sargasso Sea, researchers observed noticeable changes in their migration patterns. This suggests that water clarity affects how deep these fish swim, which can alter the prey they hunt and their exposure to predators like large sharks.

Why Mid-Sized Fish Matter More Than We Thought

"We always talk about the mesopelagic layer like it's this giant buffet for big predators -- but we've been skipping over the species in the middle," said WHOI biologist Camrin Braun, the study's senior author and principal investigator of WHOI's Marine Predators Group. "These mesopelagic fish are doing the hard work of connecting the deep ocean to the surface food web. If we don't understand them, we're basically trying to solve a puzzle with the middle pieces missing."

Together, the findings highlight how overlooked species in the ocean's twilight zone play an outsized role in shaping marine food webs and the behavior of some of the ocean's largest predators.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant scientific discovery about mid-sized fish linking deep and surface ocean ecosystems, revealing important ecological dynamics that affect marine food webs and predator behavior. This has broad environmental significance by enhancing understanding of ocean biodiversity and ecosystem functioning, with detailed context on the research methods and implications.
articles.personality_title: Scientists uncover key fish linking deep and surface ocean life
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Large predators like sharks spend hours in the ocean’s twilight zone, a dim area between 200 and 1,000 meters deep. This zone has a lot of life, but mostly tiny creatures, so scientists wondered why big animals stay there so long.

**What happened** – Researchers at Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution used satellite tags to track mid-sized fish called bigscale pomfret for the first time. These fish live deep during the day and swim up at night to feed. The study showed their movements change depending on water clarity, which affects their role in the ocean food chain.

**Impact** – This discovery reveals that mid-sized fish are a vital link connecting deep and surface ocean ecosystems. They help transfer energy from small deep-sea creatures up to big predators like sharks. Understanding these fish fills a missing piece in how ocean food webs work and explains why large predators spend time in deep waters.

**What's next step** – Scientists plan to study more mid-sized fish species and how environmental changes, like water clarity, affect their behavior. This could improve knowledge of ocean health and help protect important marine species.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Tracking mid-sized fish like the bigscale pomfret reveals how they connect deep and surface ocean life, explaining the behavior of large predators and the ocean’s food web.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les scientifiques découvrent un poisson clé reliant la vie profonde et de surface de l’océan
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les grands prédateurs comme les requins passent des heures dans la zone crépusculaire de l’océan, une zone sombre entre 200 et 1 000 mètres de profondeur. Cette zone contient beaucoup de vie, mais surtout de très petits organismes, ce qui a poussé les scientifiques à se demander pourquoi les grands animaux y restent si longtemps.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Des chercheurs de l’Institut océanographique Woods Hole ont utilisé des balises satellites pour suivre pour la première fois un poisson de taille moyenne appelé pomfret à grande échelle. Ces poissons vivent en profondeur le jour et remontent la nuit pour se nourrir. L’étude a montré que leurs déplacements changent selon la clarté de l’eau, ce qui influence leur rôle dans la chaîne alimentaire océanique.

**Impact** – Cette découverte montre que les poissons de taille moyenne sont un lien essentiel entre les écosystèmes profonds et de surface de l’océan. Ils aident à transférer l’énergie des petits organismes profonds vers les grands prédateurs comme les requins. Comprendre ces poissons comble une pièce manquante dans le fonctionnement des chaînes alimentaires marines et explique pourquoi les grands prédateurs restent en profondeur.

**Prochaine étape** – Les scientifiques prévoient d’étudier davantage d’espèces de poissons de taille moyenne et comment les changements environnementaux, comme la clarté de l’eau, influencent leur comportement. Cela pourrait améliorer la connaissance de la santé des océans et aider à protéger des espèces marines importantes.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Le suivi des poissons comme le pomfret à grande échelle montre comment ils relient la vie profonde et de surface de l’océan, expliquant le comportement des grands prédateurs et la chaîne alimentaire marine.
articles.personality_title_es: Científicos descubren pez clave que conecta la vida profunda y superficial del océano
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Grandes depredadores como los tiburones pasan horas en la zona crepuscular del océano, un área oscura entre 200 y 1,000 metros de profundidad. Esta zona tiene mucha vida, pero en su mayoría organismos muy pequeños, por lo que los científicos se preguntaban por qué los animales grandes permanecen tanto tiempo allí.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores del Instituto Oceanográfico Woods Hole usaron etiquetas satelitales para rastrear por primera vez a un pez de tamaño mediano llamado pomfret de gran escala. Estos peces viven en profundidad durante el día y suben por la noche para alimentarse. El estudio mostró que sus movimientos cambian según la claridad del agua, lo que afecta su papel en la cadena alimentaria del océano.

**Impacto** – Este descubrimiento revela que los peces medianos son un vínculo vital que conecta los ecosistemas profundos y superficiales del océano. Ayudan a transferir energía de pequeños organismos profundos a grandes depredadores como los tiburones. Entender estos peces completa una pieza faltante sobre cómo funcionan las cadenas alimentarias oceánicas y explica por qué los grandes depredadores pasan tiempo en aguas profundas.

**Próximo paso** – Los científicos planean estudiar más especies de peces medianos y cómo los cambios ambientales, como la claridad del agua, afectan su comportamiento. Esto podría mejorar el conocimiento sobre la salud del océano y ayudar a proteger especies marinas importantes.

**Frase clave** – Rastrear peces medianos como el pomfret de gran escala revela cómo conectan la vida profunda y superficial del océano, explicando el comportamiento de grandes depredadores y la cadena alimentaria marina.

articles.personality_title: Cycads use heat to attract beetles for pollination
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Cycads are ancient plants that rely on beetles to help them reproduce. Pollination happens when beetles carry pollen from one plant to another, but how these plants attract beetles in the dark was not fully understood.

**What happened** – Scientists discovered that some cycads warm up their reproductive parts to give off infrared heat signals. These signals can be detected by special beetles that are active at night. This warming happens just when the plants are ready to reproduce, helping beetles find them in the dark.

**Impact** – This finding shows a new way plants and animals communicate using heat instead of light or smell. It helps us understand more about how plants survive and reproduce in nature. Knowing this could help protect cycads and their beetle partners, which are important for healthy ecosystems.

**What's next step** – Researchers plan to study more types of plants and beetles to see if infrared signals are common. They may also explore how this knowledge can improve conservation efforts for rare plant species.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Some cycads heat up their flowers to send invisible heat signals that guide beetles for pollination in the dark.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les cycas utilisent la chaleur pour attirer les coléoptères pollinisateurs
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les cycas sont des plantes anciennes qui dépendent des coléoptères pour leur reproduction. La pollinisation se fait lorsque ces insectes transportent le pollen d’une plante à l’autre, mais on ne comprenait pas bien comment les plantes attiraient les coléoptères dans l’obscurité.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Des scientifiques ont découvert que certains cycas réchauffent leurs parties reproductrices pour émettre des signaux infrarouges. Ces signaux peuvent être détectés par des coléoptères spécialement adaptés, actifs la nuit. Ce réchauffement se produit au moment où la plante est prête à se reproduire, aidant les coléoptères à les trouver dans le noir.

**Impact** – Cette découverte révèle une nouvelle façon pour les plantes et les animaux de communiquer par la chaleur plutôt que par la lumière ou l’odeur. Cela permet de mieux comprendre comment les plantes survivent et se reproduisent dans la nature. Ces connaissances pourraient aider à protéger les cycas et leurs coléoptères, essentiels pour des écosystèmes sains.

**Prochaine étape** – Les chercheurs vont étudier d’autres plantes et coléoptères pour voir si les signaux infrarouges sont courants. Ils pourraient aussi utiliser ces informations pour améliorer la conservation des espèces de plantes rares.

**Conclusion en une phrase** – Certains cycas chauffent leurs fleurs pour envoyer des signaux de chaleur invisibles qui guident les coléoptères pour la pollinisation dans l’obscurité.
articles.personality_title_es: Los cícadas usan calor para atraer escarabajos polinizadores
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los cícadas son plantas antiguas que dependen de escarabajos para reproducirse. La polinización ocurre cuando los escarabajos llevan el polen de una planta a otra, pero no se sabía bien cómo estas plantas atraían a los escarabajos en la oscuridad.

**Qué pasó** – Científicos descubrieron que algunos cícadas calientan sus órganos reproductores para emitir señales de infrarrojos. Estas señales pueden ser detectadas por escarabajos especialmente adaptados que están activos de noche. Este calentamiento ocurre justo cuando las plantas están listas para reproducirse, ayudando a los escarabajos a encontrarlas en la oscuridad.

**Impacto** – Este hallazgo muestra una nueva forma en que las plantas y los animales se comunican usando calor en lugar de luz o olor. Ayuda a entender mejor cómo las plantas sobreviven y se reproducen en la naturaleza. Este conocimiento podría ayudar a proteger a los cícadas y sus escarabajos, que son importantes para ecosistemas saludables.

**Próximo paso** – Los investigadores planean estudiar más tipos de plantas y escarabajos para ver si las señales infrarrojas son comunes. También podrían explorar cómo usar esta información para mejorar los esfuerzos de conservación de especies raras.

**Resumen en una frase** – Algunos cícadas calientan sus flores para enviar señales de calor invisibles que guían a los escarabajos para la polinización en la oscuridad.
